comments.commentBody:
Mitt Romney expects to buy the US Presidency with unlimited funding for attack ads in the primaries and the general election. It may work for him.

I'm sure this is exactly what Madison and Jefferson had in mind when they penned the First Amendment to the Constitution: unlimited power for wealthy interests to corrupt the political process with mindless attack adds on television. I'm really glad that the US Supreme Court is getting back to the true and original intent of the Constitution.

Welcome to the shredding of free speech, the Constitution and American democracy.

The Oligarchs and Plutocrats can speak as much as they want since cash equals speech. However, you and I don't have cash to burn, and so our speech is never heard.

All the reason to vote against all Republicans since they support this trashing of America.

All campaign contributions should be illegal since they represent bribes, distortions and/or lies.

What a disgrace the Bush Court Citizens United case is to the United States.
I think it will start in November 2012.

The Secret Rich (1%) have hijacked our democracy with secret money. Who cares if they savage each other in the Republican race? When will the mass the Common People rise up and take back our democracy from the Koch brother, worthless Supreme Court, and corporate monopolies? It might happen sooner than some think. I certainly hope so.
Sadly, true.

Money rules in America. Republican Pacs will destroy Democrats in 2012 with a nonstop barrage of negative ads. Look what the Bob Perry Swift Boat Ads did to John Kerry - turned a war hero into a villain. Negative ads work.

Mitt Romney is a proven liar but a very rich one with very rich friends. He will most likely win the primary and the presidential election. The US turning into a Banana Republic will become a reality. The rich will win, as usual.
democracy in the US is an illusion, corruption is as rampant as it is in China, just slightly veiled.

Anyone who finds the influence of wealth on the current American political system surprising does not know much about the history of their own country. America has _never_ been particularly "democratic," in that the distribution of power has always favored the few and vast swathes of the population have almost always been disfranchised and largely remain so beyond local politics (the U.S. population is 50% female, for example, but there are a mere 17 female Senators). True, there has been, at times, less of a political disparity between the rich and the poor (e.g 1940s-1970s). But the wealthy have generally held sway over American politics, e.g. the merchant & landholding elite of the 1770s, the southern plantation owners of the 1840s, or the urban industrialists of the 1870s. The two-party system has also encouraged entrenched political "machines" at the municipal and state levels. Since the Reagan era, mass media has made it possible for such entrenched interest to manipulate politics at the national level (this has been the case at least ).

And now, the Supreme Court, which is entirely a product of this oligarchy, has given free reign for wealth to sway the legions poorly educated and strongly opinionated voters who believe what they see on television. What other choice do they have? It's either the establishment or ineffectual idealists like Ralph Nader.

So yes, be outraged, but don't act surprised.
I always loved that quote.  This situation is so sad for all lovers of democracy.

'Those who make peaceful revolution impossible will make violent revolution inevitable.'

John F. Kennedy, In a speech at the White House, 1962

If there cannot be a resolution of the farcical majority opinion and decsion in Citizens United, I suspect that there will be what President Kennedy foresaw -- violence when enough people reach the point that they feel their ability to exercise their Constitutional rights are being abridged.

I couldn't agree more! Watching the necrotising fasciitis that Gingrich unleashed on American politics consume its creator would be the greatest spectacle since Raymond Burr and Godzilla. May Shelly, move over!

Perhaps neither man is suitable for the tough job of president of the United States. When the slate boils down to either of two men...and both are clearly too 'controlled' to be effective on behalf of the ordinary people of the US...perhaps its time to call a 'time out' and disqualify both of them...somehow. Why vote for a new president who can only mouth disgraceful slurs and sling barbs at a time when people need true, honest leadership? Neither of these two men will restore the lustre on the US; it will make the Statue of Liberty cringe with shame.

If Gingrich gets the nomination, you will see vitriol and mendacity writ larger than ever before in American politics. The effect will be shocking. The hatred and bigotry it will unleash in like-minded people will resemble the suppuration of a gangrenous wound, festering and in need of amputation. This macabre spectacle could be our body politic's means of purging itself, if only for the time being, of the evil so powerfully rooted in our public discourse. In any case, its success in grafting itself, from the Congress onto the White House is unimaginable. It would be morbidly fascinating, to watch the originator of the decline of public discourse into 24/7 slash and burn, have that turned instead on him, 24/7, until he implodes, much like the wicked witch of the north. "I'm melting....!!!!!" Now, I'd pay a big price to watch that happen.

Granted, this paragraph isn't from the mouths of voters, but presumably it reflects their thinking:

"Democrats and Republicans alike have singled out the $2.8 million-and-counting air deluge as the biggest factor in Mr. Gingrich’s precipitous drop in polls of Iowa voters and Mitt Romney’s corresponding rise, reshaping the critical first contest of the Republican primary season to Mr. Romney’s benefit."

The NYT published an article yesterday on how the voters think and decide. Warning: It's funny but not pretty.

http://www.nytimes.com/2011/12/30/us/politics/voters-say-republican-cand...

This type of journalism around election issues is good but it reifies the same 'power of the dollar' the author seeks to expose as cruel and unethical. Instead of only quoting the makers and institutional 'readers' of political ad culture, journalists should be out there talking to the people. How do these ads affect what local people think about the candidates? How those watching the ads feel about the fall-out from Citizens United on campaigns? It's great that the NYT takes a critical stance towards super-PACs, but what about the voters? Instead of pre-determining that 'our democracy is dead,' as some of the commentators present here, we should be able to see and assess what's really going on at the 'grassroots.' Unless, of course, we've long since sold our moral independence and we all swallow whole what comes through the old TV. I don't believe it and I don't think the NYT does either.  So let's change the discourse, let's democratize our sources.

Re: "Frankly, if Gingrich hadn't done so many moronic things for these ads to point out, no amount of Super PAC money would make a difference."

If Gingrich hadn't a shady past, the Romney campaign would probably just make up stuff. It certainly hasn't shown itself reluctant to make up stuff about Obama.

Re: "And while Romney's surrogates may be saying nasty things in ads, Gingrich is perfectly willing to say hateful things with his own mouth."

Which makes Gingrich more honest--in this respect, anyway. (In other respects, not so much.)
He just hasn't bothered to raise the money to do so, ekeizer.

Frankly, if Gingrich hadn't done so many moronic things for these ads to point out, no amount of Super PAC money would make a difference. And while Romney's surrogates may be saying nasty things in ads, Gingrich is perfectly willing to say hateful things with his own mouth.

"The very nature of democracy demands that every vote carry equal weight and, by extension, every voice."

"One man, one vote" is not the same thing as "One man, one voice." How should we ensure that every voice is given equal weight? Should people who would rather remain silent be forced to speak? Otherwise we would all have to say nothing to keep things "equal." This is a fundamental misreading of the First Amendment. There are good arguments against the Citizens United ruling, but this is not one of them.

RoboRomney has no moral compass. He is clueless when it comes to principle, although he natters on about it endlessly. He is an empty suit, already contaminated by his lifetime of taking advantage of the helpless. He is in the race because he can fund himself from his gains from putting thousands of people out of work. If he gets the chance to face Obama, he will melt like a little wax candle in front of a roaring fire.

Its the Supreme Court, Bill.  America is no longer a system of one-man, one-vote. The Supreme Court has ruled that corporations and unions and PACs and such are citizens also and thus you and I no longer 'elect' our representatives; the power of money is calling the shots. The American electorate is too busy watching TV to know/care what is going on. Government "of the people, by the people and for the people" is history unless we turn off Dancing with the Stars and have a second Revolution.

After all, there is nothing wrong with negative ads if they're true.  And all the negative ads against Gingrich that I've seen are eminently true.  That also applies to the other Republican candidates with the possible exception of Jon Huntsman.  One doesn't have to make stuff up about these bottom feeders.
The most important bit of news here is that I need to look for a new hotel chain.
Except the fact that there's no reasonable explanation for newt's rise in the first place.

"The independent fact checking organization to call foul whenever the truth is violated" DID exist - it was called journalism.

But its credentials have been diluted by the likes of "news" channels that have nothing to do with reporting "journalistic" news; and legitimate channels that take their cues from blogs or other unsubstantiated sources. Technology makes the scoop hard to get, and sensation sells.

Ad dollars that used to fund print/broadcast journalism, now go to bloggers or other venues that "reinforce" the advertiser's message to a select audience.

Who sits in front of the evening news or shells out $1 for a paper anymore? It's all online. Journalism is very much needed, and needs to adapt to the new media. How? Don't know. Just keeping my fingers crossed.

The current political circus, funded by secret groups and corporate cash, makes a mockery of the American system of elections. How can we tolerate an entire year of this fraudlent election buying and propaganda spreading.

Political campaign reform, finance reform, is an absolute must. We should limit the campaign season to 3 months, and mandate free media time for presentations and a limited number of debates. And create an independant fact checking organization to call foul whenever the truth is violated.

Jon, Dubya and his VP were the turning point that brought us to the chaotic mess we are experiencing now. The GOP offering today is a shallow joke. But, more importantly, the American electorate is the really joke.
dresser: stay in chicago where you obviously belong. Too bad about Avery! He'll be missed, and if does go unclaimed, I hope we'll see him back in NYC soon.

Ali should ask. Betsy should feel free to say no. When I was a new parent (granted, 18 months is not so new) so much of my new social terrain was assumed to be with the baby that I rsvp'ed yes to an event and only later realized it was probably meant to be kid free and I didn't have a sitter. I called the hostess to explain. With true understanding (as a mom herself) she said it was to be a kid-free event, and so I declined the invite. No harm, no foul. My would-be hostess was glad I wanted to come enough that I would do so with baby in tow, and also glad that I respected her wish for a child-free environment. There were other invitations later. And Ali or her husband can still attend and celebrate, or neither, as they wish.

Once upon a time rooting for a local team was the only choice. But with the accessibility of broadcasts and information, it makes it possible to follow many different teams and to do so in detail.

Which means a fan is not captive to the local ownership and whatever players they decide to assemble. Many owners are stupid and greedy and it is reflected in their teams. Why root for such teams or spend money on them?

Something just grabs your fancy, just strikes you in the in the right way at the right time. Not really love, but akin to it. Like love, it can fill you up or break your heart.

Started with me with Stan the Man, the greatest ever. Followed by so many many other great Redbirds, so many wonderful moments.

Changing teams simply because one lives in proximity to another seems hollow and heartless. Faithfulness is rewarded with joy, even in defeat. They're still my team, always my team.

Besides, as I tell NY fans, rooting for the Yanks is like being on the wrong side of the David vs. Goliath battle. What's the fun in that?

Go Cards!
The Republican party  is beginning to show it's true colors. All of the mess they have created since Obama has become president is beginning to come home to roost.
Umm... the 1% will be buying it regardless of who wins, Romney or Obama. Both politicians dance to the same tune.  They have no choice.
Re the reply by "Sane," do you really believe that Al Gore would have nominated Scalia clones like Roberts and Alito to the Court?
This is how the richest 1% will attempt to buy the election for Romney. Surprise, surprise.
As someone put it, we'll believe corporations are people when Texas executes one.
